issues.description: The problem UML and the solution expect Stock.findStockIngredient(String) — a single-argument method — but the template's Stock class only provides findStockIngredient(String name, boolean caseSensitive). Meanwhile, the template's own add(String) and take(String) methods call findStockIngredient(ingredient) (single argument). This creates a signature mismatch that will cause compilation errors and confuses students about the correct method signature to implement/use.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the template's Stock.findStockIngredient signature match the problem specification and the solution: add or replace it with public StockIngredient findStockIngredient(String name). Alternatively, overload the template method by adding a single-argument findStockIngredient(String) that delegates to the existing two-argument variant (e.g., calling findStockIngredient(name, true)). Also ensure add() and take() use the same single-argument method. This will remove the compilation error and align template, solution, and specification.

issues.description: The problem statement (and the solution) describe a Stock.findStockIngredient(String) method with a single String parameter, but the template implementation provides findStockIngredient(String, boolean caseSensitive) (two parameters). Additionally, the template's Main (commented example) calls findStockIngredient("Bacon") with a single argument. This mismatch in method signature between the template and the problem/solution can confuse students: they will search for or expect a single-argument method as shown in the exercise diagram and examples but find only a two-argument variant in the starter code.
issues.suggested_fix: Align the template with the problem diagram and solution by providing a single-parameter findStockIngredient(String name) method. Options: (a) add an overloaded findStockIngredient(String) that delegates to the existing two-parameter version (e.g. defaulting case sensitivity), or (b) replace the two-parameter method with the single-parameter signature used in the problem/solution. This will make the example Main and the exercise diagram match the starter code and reduce student confusion.
